Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the South Sudanese government is handing out grants worth $41.4 million to entrepreneurs and farmers. The finance ministry has stated that it never announced any such grant and dismissed it as a hoax.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as the only source mentioned is a Facebook page called "South Sudan ministry of finance and planning," which is later revealed to be a bogus page run from Kenya.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the grant announcement on the Facebook page is legitimate without verifying its authenticity.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the claim is a hoax created by hackers to deceive people into providing their personal information.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the amount of money being handed out as grants, stating it to be $41.4 million, which is not supported by any official announcement.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in this claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by relying on false information posted on a bogus Facebook page.
